ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: The course looks at colonialism in Africa from several standpoints, covering its implementation, entrenchment, and legacies. It approaches colonialism from social science as well as humanity perspectives, and does a great deal to add nuance to most traditional narratives of colonialism.
Colonialism in Africa was a review of the historiographical literature on the different issues related to colonialism. Learned a great deal and would definitely recommend the course.
I would. If anything, it is unfortunate that more students are not interested in African topics.
I would recommend it for anyone interested in British history or European imperialism generally.

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: Course gave me a deeper understanding of the history of colonialism in Africa that has better informed my study of development on the continent.
This course combined theoretical readings with case studies to provide a good overview of the historiography on colonial Africa.
It has done much to prepare me for future teaching on comparative colonialism and comparative background for my dissertation work.
